I've been playing this game for years and have watched this game go from a tech demo to what it is today. The devs really do care about this game and continue to add so many new features and gameplay elements that make driving fun and interesting. Sure, crashing is fun, but the meat is in the missions. You can do all sorts of jobs including, truck deliveries, bus routes, police chases, etc. All these things are soon coming together in the upcoming career mode that will add an economy which will allow you to purchase and maintain your car and really make it yours. The game does support mods, however I personally don't mod the game much as it is still in early access but you can definitely add mods through the in game mod repository.

As I mentioned in the top line, you do need a somewhat beefy computer to run this. I definitely recommend having a system with 32GB of ram although you should be fine with 16. The devs have been working on performance over the years and the game has shown great progress with the upcoming Vulkan API. With that being said, I would still recommend having this run on a modern PC and not a potato. (Unless you like pain I guess?)

This concludes my review. I would greatly recommend giving this a shot. The gameplay is great, mods make it even better, and the controls feel good for controller, keyboard and mouse, and of course wheel and pedals. Also, BeamMP multiplayer adds a little extra spice to the game. It's not a part of the game as it is a third party app, but it allows you to play with friends on multiplayer servers. Very fun!

BeamNG.drive is one of the most distinctive and ambitious vehicle simulators ever developed. Built around an advanced soft-body physics engine, the game focuses on accurately simulating how vehicles behave and react to forces, impacts, and the environment. Unlike traditional racing titles that use simplified damage models, BeamNG attempts to bring a near-real-world level of detail to every crash, bend, and mechanical failure. This design philosophy places it in a category of its own, appealing not only to racing fans but also engineering enthusiasts, content creators, modders, and players who enjoy open-ended experimentation. From the moment you load into a map, the game communicates that it is less about competition and more about the physics-driven story you create behind the wheel.

One of BeamNG.drive‚Äôs greatest strengths is the incredibly detailed soft-body physics simulation, where every vehicle is constructed using a system of interconnected nodes and beams. This allows cars to deform, break, and react to collisions in ways that closely mirror real-world engineering. When you hit a guardrail or fly off a cliff, the resulting damage is not pre-scripted ‚Äî it‚Äôs calculated in real time based on speed, angle, structural integrity, and force distribution. This means no crash ever looks the same twice, giving the game endless replayability. Even low-speed impacts feel different depending on where the car is struck, how heavy it is, and what part of the frame absorbs the energy. Few games offer this level of consistent realism, which is why BeamNG often goes viral for its crash compilation videos and stunt experiments.

In addition to its impressive physics engine, BeamNG.drive includes a surprisingly robust variety of vehicles, each with unique handling characteristics. You can find everything from compact hatchbacks and luxury sedans to semi-trucks, rock crawlers, drift cars, classic muscle, rally monsters, and even experimental prototypes. The diversity isn‚Äôt just cosmetic ‚Äî each vehicle feels fundamentally different to drive. A heavy pickup truck lumbers around corners with weighty inertia, while a lightweight rally car darts quickly along gravel roads, reacting sharply to every input. There are also numerous engine, transmission, and suspension configurations available, allowing players to tailor vehicles to their preferred driving style. This variety ensures that players constantly discover new experiences even after hundreds of hours of gameplay.

The game‚Äôs environments further enhance the experience. BeamNG.drive includes a collection of large, intricately designed maps that range from sprawling cities to quiet rural towns, mountainous switchback roads, tropical islands, desert canyons, industrial testing facilities, and more. Each map feels unique, with realistic lighting, varied terrain types, and countless places to experiment. Whether you are performing high-speed highway tests, drifting around tight corners, stress-testing suspension on rocky trails, or launching vehicles off cliffs, the environments feel like real-world automotive playgrounds. These maps serve as canvases for creativity, allowing players to construct their own challenges, cinematic scenes, or physics experiments without unnecessary restrictions.

BeamNG.drive is a fantastic game for several reasons:

1. **Realistic Physics**: The game features an advanced soft-body physics engine that simulates vehicle dynamics realistically. This means crashes and vehicle behavior feel very authentic, making it a lot of fun to experiment with different scenarios.

2. **Variety of Vehicles**: BeamNG offers a wide range of vehicles, from everyday cars to unique creations. Players can customize and modify their vehicles, which adds a personal touch to the experience.

3. **Open World**: The game includes various environments and maps to explore, whether you want to race, perform stunts, or just drive around. This openness allows for tons of creative gameplay options.

4. **Modding Community**: The game has a thriving modding community that constantly creates new vehicles, maps, and scenarios. This keeps the game fresh and gives players plenty of new content to enjoy.

5. **Crash Testing**: Many players enjoy the ability to test the limits of vehicles and see what happens during crashes. It's both entertaining and educational, as it provides insight into how vehicles are built and how they respond to impacts.

6. **Realistic Damage Modeling**: The way vehicles deform and take damage in BeamNG is incredibly detailed, which adds to the immersion and realism.

7. **Challenge and Creativity**: The game allows players to set their own challenges or participate in community challenges, fostering a sense of accomplishment and creativity.

Overall, BeamNG.drive combines realism with fun, making it a popular choice for car enthusiasts and gamers alike!

This is an amazing sandbox game that has a passionate development team behind it. At the time of this review, the Devs are still delivering continuous updates and have been for a long time. It's honestly up there among some of the most fun driving games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. I'd go as far as to say this one of the most innovative realistic driving/racing games we have right now.  

There is a unique variety of different vehicles to choose from and a decent amount of different maps to explore. Every vehicle handles differently and the surfaces you drive on affect your cars grip in different ways. While you do have the ability to customize cars to your liking, I personally have not used this feature enough to comment on it extensively. From what I've used so far, I can say that it works fine and that you can change a lot of different parameters of a vehicle (from the color and texture of a car's paint job to altering the vehicles suspension). 

The deformation physics and the mechanics simulation doesn't need much explaining. Without going into to much detail, I found the amount of detail packed into the vehicles to be engaging, satisfying, immersive, and most importantly, fun! It does its job VERY well in that regard. After all, BeamNG.drive is a Soft-Body physics simulator first. If you wanna destroy a vehicle so bad that it barely looks like a car (while having tons of fun doing it), BeamNG is the game for you. If you decide that you'd rather test drive a variety of vehicles and simply appreciate the details of each individual car, this games got you covered too! 

Some maps are larger and more detailed than others, but they all have there place in this game. Each of these maps have a number of "missions" or "scenarios" that you can do. I found most of these to be fun to complete, and just as funny to fail miserably at. Some of them are kinda easy and most of them have a good level of difficulty, but some of the missions might seem disproportionately harder than the others. This might just be a skill issue on my end tho. 

Sidenote: Something that this game gets right that surprisingly not many games get right is the sense of speed while driving! For a soft-body physics simulator, this game has great camera work.

This is already a fairly detailed game in terms of the physics and customization, but if you find yourself looking for more, this game has integrated mod support! So even if your not comfortable with going to a external website to mod your game, there are still plenty of ways to customize your experience. I will say that this game tends to use a LOT of your PC resources, so be prepared to lower some graphics settings if you need some extra performance. Oh, and about the graphics, this is not the most graphically impressive game of all time. The game looks nice enough to where it is not a problem. For a 10 year old game, it actually looks great but don't expect hyper realistic textures or anything like that. What I will say is that the LOD pop-in is noticeable. Just like with anything else, you will likely learn to ignore it after a while, but it is there. It doesn't ruin the game by any means, but I would say it affects immersion. I hope that the developers will add an option to mitigate this LOD issue in the future.    

Of course, this game is not perfect. Overall the game has become pretty stable over the years. At times, it can be a bit buggy. BeamNG.drive can become prone to stuttering, freezing, and sometimes crashing during extremely resource intensive in-game events (I'm assuming this is due to the amount of physics calculations being done at times). IMPORTAINT: Just to be VERY clear, this isn't really an issue during normal gameplay. It'll probably affect you if you crash into another car going insanely fast (usually with the help of a car mod) or if there are an extremely huge amount of collisions happening at once (also usually with the help of a mod). Of course, the more vehicles you spawn, the more resource it will take to run the game, so be careful that. Sometimes, the game will just pause itself your game to prevent an outright game crash (which can be funny sometimes). Even if your PC can handle this game just fine, depending on how crazy you get while messing around, you'll probably experience at least some stutter/freezing when pushing this game to its absolute limits. 

*Remember, If you do have trouble with crashing or other severe performance related issues and you happen to have mods installed, try disabling your mods to see if that fixes the problem. 

A common criticism of Beam currently is about the tires. The tire physics do not seem to be super accurate or detailed and the Devs know this. The good thing about this is that at the time of this review, the Devs announced some time ago that they have extensively tested and researched IRL tire behavior to create a more realistic and dynamic tire model. That is something to look forward to in the future but it is not currently in the game at the time of this review. Something else to note is that there are no built-in temporal upscaling methods in this game (DLSS 2.0+, FSR 2.0+, XESS) and the anti-aliasing options are pretty limited, so expect to see some jagged edges at lower resolutions. There is a built-in resolution scaling slider tho. Just thought I should mention this in case that fact was important to anyone reading this.  

If I had to think of one thing that disappoints me about this game is that there is currently no built in online multiplayer without utilizing mods. From the official BeamNG website: "Online multiplayer is a common request, and we are keeping an eye on it, but has never been part of the originally promised features. It is unlikely to happen in the short term". It's probably not happening anytime soon but I promise the game is still great as is.  

As far as singleplayer sandbox driving games go, BeamNG.drive is one of the best when it comes to having freedom over your gameplay. I'd say that this game is 100% worth getting (Especially if you have a racing wheel).

There are many reasons why I enjoy playing this game.

Second, I really like the career mode because it has more realism for the times when I want to do progression.

Fourth, mhm.

Great game for those who want to do pretty much anything vehicle related. Racing, flying, offroading and super realistic mayhem. The sky is the limit for what you can do.
